0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Levobupivacaine marketed in the United States under the brand name Chirocaine(R) was discontinued on 9/30/2003.
  • Local anesthesia: retrobulbar anesthesia, 5 mL of 0.5% solution
  • Local anesthesia: local anesthetic, 60 mL of 0.25% solution (150 mg)
  • Obstetric pain: 10 to 20 mL of 0.25% solution EPIDURAL bolus (25 to 50 mg)
  • Postoperative pain: 4 to 10 mL/hr of 0.125% or 0.25% solution EPIDURAL infusion (5 to 25 mg/hour); 0.125% used only in combination with fentanyl or clonidine
  • Regional anesthesia: peribulbar infiltration, 5 to 15 mL of 0.75% solution (37.5 to 112.5 mg)
  • Regional anesthesia: peripheral block, 30 mL or 0.4 mL/kg of 0.25% to 0.5% solution (75 to 150 mg (1 to 2 mg/kg))
  • Regional anesthesia: epidural (surgical), 10 to 20 mL of 0.5 to 0.75% solution (50 to 150 mg)
  • Regional anesthesia: epidural (cesarean section) 20 to 30 mL of 0.5% solution (100 to 150 mg)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Levobupivacaine marketed in the United States under the brand name Chirocaine(R) was discontinued on 9/30/2003.
  • safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Levobupivacaine marketed in the United States under the brand name Chirocaine(R) was discontinued on 9/30/2003.
  • Local anesthesia
  • Obstetric pain
  • Postoperative pain
  • Regional anesthesia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to amide local anesthetics
  • hypersensitivity to levobupivacaine, or bupivacaine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• avoid 0.75% solution in obstetrical patients
  • avoid unintended intravenous injection; may result in cardiovascular arrest and prolonged resuscitation
  • avoid unintended intravascular or intrathecal injection during epidural administration; may lead to high plasma level or very high spinal anesthesia resulting in apnea, severe hypotension, or loss of consciousness
  • not recommended for emergency situations where fast onset of surgical anesthesia is necessary
  • should not be used in intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier block); risk of reaching toxic blood levels
  • should not be used in production of obstetrical paracervical block anesthesia; additional risk of fetal bradycardia and death
  • hypotensive patients or those with cardiovascular disease, especially heart block
  • infection at injection site
  • injections in head and neck area; may produce adverse reactions similar to unintentional large doses of intravascular injection
  • liver disease or conditions associated with reduced hepatic blood flow
  • patient receiving other local anesthetics
  • peripheral nerve block using large volumes of higher concentrations of levobupivacaine; increased risk of dose-related cardiac toxicity
  • repeated injections may cause significant increases in plasma levels

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Levobupivacaine: AAP: Drugs for which the effect on nursing infants is unknown but may be of concern.
  • Levobupivacaine: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• blood pressure, heart rate, muscle twitching, peripheral nerve stimulation
  • blood gases, ECG, respirations
  • signs of CNS toxicity

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, dizziness, or fever.
  • Instruct patients receiving spinal or epidural bupivacaine to report signs/symptoms of respiratory paralysis (high spinal effects), muscle weakness, hypotension, or urinary retention.
  • Warn patients receiving all routes of bupivacaine to report signs/symptoms of unintended IV or intrathecal injections which include CNS or cardiovascular toxicity.
